I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the country programming mission in December 2009, the Government of the 
People’s Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide 
technical assistance (TA) for capacity development for railway track maintenance. A fact-finding 
mission visited the PRC in October 2010 and reached agreement with the government on the 
TA’s impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, 
and  terms  of  reference  for  consultants.  The  TA  design  and  monitoring  framework  is  in 
Appendix 1. The TA is in the ADB’s technical assistance program for the PRC for 2010.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Given the PRC’s large land area and population, railways play a vital role in transport. 
They are an accessible, environment-friendly, less-land demanding, energy-efficient, and low 
cost mass transport mode for people and goods. By providing efficient transport and opening up 
less-accessible regions, railways have helped to expand economic opportunities and spread 
these to poorer provinces, and have thereby contributed to growth of employment and incomes, 
and to poverty reduction. 
 
3.  For  the  last  10–15  years,  the  government  has  been  prioritizing  railway  network 
expansion and optimization to support rapid economic development. By the end of 2009, the 
railway network was 86,000 kilometers (km) in length. This represented a 37.8% increase since 
1995, including 6,300 km of new high-speed railways. Over this period, passenger traffic (in 
passenger-km) increased by 222% and freight (in ton-km) by 193%. In spite of this track 
expansion,  the  PRC  railways  remain  the  busiest  in  the  world.  Traffic  density  reached 
45.58 million ton-km/km in 2007.2 Railway transport is still unable to meet the rising demand for 
passenger  and  freight  transportation  resulting  from  the  PRC’s  high  economic  growth  and 
urbanization. The government therefore intends to construct 16,000 km of high-speed railways 
by 2016 and expand the railway network to over 120,000 km by 2020.  
 
4.  Efficient track maintenance is essential for the competitiveness, condition, reliability, and 
safety of the railway. In a well-maintained rail network (i) the track system3 will enable trains to 
move fast, rolling stock to need less maintenance, and accident risks to be minimized, (ii) the 
periods when train operations are stopped for track maintenance are minimized, therefore 
allowing higher track usage; and (iii) the cost of necessary maintenance are lower. 
 
5.  The  rapid  development  of  the  PRC  railways  has  brought  new  challenges  for  track 
maintenance capacity. The quantity of maintenance to be undertaken has grown quickly due to 
network expansion and increased track usage. Between 2000 and 2009, double-track railways 
increased by 57.2% in length to reach 33,000 km in 2009, and electrified lines increased by 
142.3% to reach 36,000 km. Twenty-six railway lines with a total length of 9,200 km are 
currently under construction, and 70 new railway projects are under review.

6.  Track maintenance on high speed railway lines poses a new challenge. More than 
7,000 km of high speed railways were put in operation in the past 3 years.4 Another 6,000 km 
will be added in the next 3 years. High-speed railways require far more stringent operating 
standards than normal lines due to the higher operating speeds. As a result, their maintenance 
needs are heavily mechanized, using the latest technologies. Many of the newly constructed 
railways are located in less-developed and poor areas, with difficult terrains such as mountains 
or  complex  geological  areas  (e.g.,  permafrost,  collapsed  loess,  seismic  belt,  soft  soil  and 
underground mined-out areas). Track maintenance in those areas is more complex, requiring 
more specialized and technically qualified staff. 
 
7.  The Ministry of Railways (MOR) has been gradually developing its track maintenance 
capacity. Track maintenance development was included in MOR’s 10th and 11th Five-Year 
Plans  and  in  the  Railway  Mid-term  and  Long-term  Development  Program  for  2020.  Key 
elements include: (i) adapting from a mostly manual, labor-intensive approach to predominantly 
mechanized maintenance in order to upgrade quality and efficiency (the normal practice of 
industrialized countries); (ii) restructuring the organization of track maintenance to improve its 
management and adjust to the new maintenance methods; (iii) establishing a track maintenance 
management  information  system  in  MOR;  and  (iv) developing  staff  capacity  to  use  new 
mechanized maintenance processes.  
 
8.  With ADB support, MOR has made significant investments to modernize its maintenance 
equipment and practices. It has procured about 1,350 sets of advanced and efficient large track 
maintenance machines (LTMMs), mainly in the last few years, at a cost of about CNY20 billion 
($2.86 billion). In its past railway projects, ADB financed the purchase of 99 sets of advanced 
LTMMs (ADB financing of $140 million). The ongoing Zhengzhou–Xi’an Railway Project5 will 
finance another $60 million for LTMMs. In the coming 5 years, MOR plans to spend a further 
CNY14 billion ($2.1 billion) on LTMMs. 
 
9.  MOR  has  also  been  restructuring  its  railway  track  maintenance  organization.  To 
strengthen the specialized management and operation of mechanized maintenance work, in 
1990–2000 MOR set up a permanent way depot responsible for mechanized track maintenance 
in each of the 18 railway administrative bureaus, and 170 mechanized track maintenance teams. 
As the needs for mechanized maintenance were growing, MOR decided to establish four new 
comprehensive maintenance centers in Beijing, Guangzhou, Shanghai, and Wuhan in 2009. 
These centers will provide integrated maintenance services to dedicated passenger railways, 
including for track, signaling, communication, electrification, and power supply maintenance. 
 
10.  Qualified and well-trained staff are essential for efficient track maintenance. MOR has 
about  276,000 employees  working  on  track  maintenance,  including  13,600  already  using 
LTMMs. However, many of them do not have any systematic training, and lack the skills and 
knowledge to use the latest LTMMs. Consequently, LTMMs are often poorly used. 
 
11.  MOR has sought to improve track maintenance staff capacity by (i) setting up a training 
center in Kunming; and (ii) conducting short-term, on-the-job training for 15,000 employees. In 
2009, heavy and regular track maintenance work by LTMMs reached 5,300 km and 25,000 km, 
respectively. However, this remains much below current needs, which are set to rise sharply as 
the new high-speed railway network is put into operation. Moreover, MOR’s current approach to

12.  Support  for  improving  railway  efficiency  and  safety,  and  railway  modernization,  is 
included  among  the  indicative  areas  for  interventions  identified  in  ADB’s  PRC  country 
partnership strategy, 2008–2010. 
 
13.  The government seeks ADB assistance to help the PRC railway obtain information on 
international best practices in mechanized maintenance, prepare a 5-year capacity development 
plan for railway track maintenance staff, and develop a training program for LTMM operators. 
The proposed TA will be an integral part of ADB’s lending and technical assistance support for 
railways development in the PRC. It will ensure that mechanized maintenance can help improve 
railway  system’s  performance  and  safety.  The  government  has  assessed  previous  ADB 
technical assistance support for railways as relevant, effective, and efficient,6 and considers it 
an important complement to the lending operations. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The impact of the proposed TA will be high quality and efficient track maintenance. The 
achievement of this impact will be demonstrated through increased productivity of maintenance 
operations and increased use of mechanized maintenance. The outcome of the TA will be 
improved capacity for track maintenance. As a result of the TA, it is expected that MOR will 
(i) adopt a 5-year plan and accompanying recommendations for the capacity development of 
track maintenance staff, (ii) carry out on a routine basis a LTMM training program reflecting best 
international practices, and (iii) increase the number of qualified full-time LTMM trainers by 
300%. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  To achieve these objectives, the TA will (i) develop a 5-year capacity development plan 
for track maintenance staff, (ii) prepare a LTMM training program and syllabus, and (iii) organize 
overseas and domestic training of LTMM trainers. 
 
16.  To prepare the 5-year capacity development plan, the TA will (i) assess current track 
maintenance staff capacity in the PRC, through conducting a survey and comparing the results 
with  track  maintenance  staff  capacity  in  industrialized  countries;  (ii)  review  the  current 
organization, policies, and operational practices for track maintenance, and compare them with 
international best practices; (iii) assess future track maintenance staffing and skills needs, 
taking into account network expansion, the increased use of mechanized maintenance, and 
innovation;  and  (iv) review  initial  and  continuous  on-the-job  training  on  track  maintenance, 
including the strategy, programs, and delivery methods, compare them with best practices in 
industrialized countries, and recommend improvements to the training.  
 
17.  The LTMM training program and syllabus will be prepared after an in-depth review of 
(i) similar training programs in industrialized countries, (ii) training materials routinely delivered

by equipment providers, and (iii) the specific needs of the PRC railways. Using the results of this 
review and within the framework of the 5-year plan, the TA will propose a training strategy and 
delivery methods for LTMM training for the various classes of staff.7 Training materials and 
teaching methods will need to be effective and adapted to the PRC, while incorporating relevant 
international best practices. The TA will also provide recommendations for potential multimedia 
training or simulation software to be developed later by MOR. 
 
18.  The TA will provide overseas training for about 10 LTMM trainers in an internationally 
recognized LTMM training institution. These trainers will help to formulate the LTMM training 
program and conduct training of about 20 other trainers using the new program. 
 
19.  Two review workshops will be held—one at the inception stage and one at the interim 
stage. A seminar will be arranged at the draft final report stage to disseminate the TA findings. 
The proposed TA will be undertaken in close consultation with relevant departments of MOR 
and  other  relevant  agencies,  taking  into  consideration  previous  studies  carried  out  by  the 
government,  ADB,  the  World  Bank,  the  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and 
Development, and multilateral agencies. MOR will provide the consultants with all relevant 
materials, studies, and reports required for undertaking the TA, and MOR will also assist in 
arranging  the  workshops  and  seminar  and  in  liaising  with  other  relevant  agencies  and 
stakeholders. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The TA is estimated to cost $500,000 equivalent. The government has requested that 
ADB finance $400,000 equivalent on a grant basis from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special 
Fund (TASF-other sources). The government will provide the remaining $100,000 in kind for 
counterpart  staff,  office  space  with  furniture,  utilities  and  telecommunication  access,  local 
transport, and other services. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
21.  The MOR will be the executing agency for the TA, which is included in the list of 2010 
TA projects for delegation to executing agencies. ADB's Central Operations Services Office 
conducted a  detailed  capacity  assessment  to  determine  MOR’s  capacity.  The  assessment 
concluded that MOR’s capacity is satisfactory and recommended approving the delegation of 
the TA to MOR, based on the enhanced partnership approach detailed in the memorandum of 
understanding between ADB and the Ministry of Finance. The MOR will be responsible for the 
administration of the TA, and ADB will focus on contract supervision, fiduciary control, and the 
dissemination of knowledge outcomes.8 
 
22.  The TA will engage an international consulting firm through the quality- and cost-based 
selection method, using a quality–cost ratio of 80:20 and a simplified technical proposal. The TA 
will require 3 international consultants (8 person-months in total) and 6 national consultants 
(20 person-months). They will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The outline terms of reference for the 
consultants are in Appendix 3.

23.  The  proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical 
Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  An  advanced 
payment facility could be used to conduct training, seminars, and workshops. Equipment will be 
procured in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to 
time). 
 
24.  The TA is expected to begin in July 2011 and be completed by December 2011. The 
consultants will submit the following reports to MOR and ADB: (i) an inception report, 3 weeks 
after work starts, (ii) an interim report after 10 weeks, (iii) a draft final report after 20 weeks, and 
(iv) a final report, 2 weeks after receipt of review comments from MOR and ADB. The final 
report will include: (i) a 5-year capacity development plan for railway track maintenance staff; 
(ii) a  LTMM  syllabus  and  training  materials;  (iii)  a  policy  note  on  how  to  enhance  track 
maintenance performance; and (iv) an executive summary. 
 
25.  Major project activities will be regularly monitored by ADB administration missions and 
MOR. Consultants’ reports will be presented at workshops and seminars organized to validate 
and disseminate their findings. Reports will be made available on ADB’s website in English and 
Chinese. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
26.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for Capacity Development for Railway Track 
Maintenance, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
1.  The proposed capacity development technical assistance (TA) to the People's Republic 
of  China  (PRC)  for  Capacity  Development  for  Railway  Track  Maintenance  will  help  the 
government and the Ministry of Railways (MOR) prepare a 5-year plan to develop staff capacity 
for  track  maintenance.  The  TA  will  (i)  assess  current  track  maintenance  staff  capacity, 
comparing the results against developed countries; (ii) review the current organization, policies, 
and operational practices for track maintenance, and compare them with international best 
practices; (iii) assess future track maintenance staffing and skills needs, taking into account 
network expansion and the increased use of mechanized maintenance; (iv) review initial and 
continuous on-the-job training for track maintenance, including the strategy, programs, and 
delivery methods, compare them with practices in industrialized countries, and recommend 
improvements for track maintenance training; and (v) prepare a LTMM training program and 
syllabus after an in-depth review of similar programs in industrialized countries. 
 
2.  The  consultants  will  perform  their  tasks  in  close  consultation  with  MOR  and  other 
relevant agencies to ensure full acceptance of the outcome of the TA. The TA will require a total 
of 28 person-months of consulting services (8 person-months international and 20 person-
months national) to be implemented over a period of 6 months, including fieldwork. 
 
3.  The international track maintenance capacity development specialist will be the team 
leader, with overall responsibility for coordinating the TA activities, and accomplishing the TA 
outputs with the support of the other international and national experts. The consultant will have 
expertise in managing interdisciplinary teams, a wide range of experience in developing staff 
capacity plans for track maintenance in large railways, and a full understanding of the LTMM 
technology and operation of railways. 
 
4.  The  international  consulting  firm  must  propose  their  own  staffing  schedule  in  the 
technical proposal, demonstrating a well-planned and balanced deployment of time for each 
team member so as to meet the TA objectives. 
 
B.  Terms of Reference

consultant will start work within 30 calendar days of the effective date of their contract.

months national)

track maintenance; 
 
(ii)  conduct a detailed survey of current track maintenance staff capacity in the PRC, 
including (a) staffing of mechanized track maintenance teams, permanent way 
depots,  divisions,  and  other  track  maintenance  units;  (b) staff  education  and

(i)  undertake a detailed review of the current status of LTMM training in MOR,

9.  The consultants will review and build on previous studies and reports prepared by the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB), the World Bank, MOR, and other development partners. They 
will review lessons learned from the experience of similar projects in other countries. 
 
10.  The consultants will organize two workshops (at the inception and interim stages) at 
which they will present the key findings so far. A seminar will be arranged at the draft final report 
stage to disseminate the findings from the study. 
 
11.  The proposed TA will be undertaken in close consultation with relevant departments of 
MOR, the government, and other relevant agencies, and will take into consideration previous 
studies carried out by the government, ADB, World Bank, the Organisation for Economic Co-
operation  and  Development,  other  multilateral  agencies,  and  bilateral  agencies.  MOR  will 
(i) provide  the  consultants  with  all  relevant  materials,  studies,  and  reports  required  for 
undertaking the TA, and (ii) assist in arranging the workshops and seminar and in liaising with 
other relevant agencies and stakeholders. 
 
C.  Reporting Requirements 
12.  The consultants will submit the following reports to MOR and ADB: (i) an inception report, 
3 weeks after work has started, (ii) an interim report after 10 weeks, (iii) a draft final report after 
20 weeks, and (iv) a final report (including a summary of key findings and recommendations in 
not more than five pages), 2 weeks after receipt of review comments from MOR and ADB.
